topic: How should we increase the general public's trust in US elections?

age: 63
sex: Male
race: White alone
ancestry: European

statements.statement: As a conservative and a manager by trade, I think restoring trust in our elections starts with transparency and accountability at every step of the process. We should require voter ID nationwide, maintain accurate voter rolls, and make sure both parties have equal, meaningful access to observe counting and audits. At the same time, states should clearly explain their procedures to the public in plain language so ordinary citizens can see how their vote is protected. If people can watch the process, understand it, and know there are real consequences for fraud or negligence, confidence in the results will grow.

statements.statement: As someone who came from Cuba and became an American by choice, I believe elections must be beyond any doubt, with strict voter ID, accurate citizenship verification, and regular audits of the vote. We should return to more in‑person, same‑day voting with paper ballots, limit mail‑in voting to clear, verified exceptions, and enforce tough penalties for any kind of fraud. Transparency at every step, with observers from all sides, is the only way people like me will fully trust the results again.

statements.statement: As someone who works in healthcare, I know systems earn trust through transparency, consistency, and accountability, and our elections should be no different. We should standardize clear voting procedures across states, invest in secure, modern voting infrastructure, and ensure bipartisan oversight and routine audits whose results are easy for the public to access and understand. I’d also like to see more nonpartisan voter education in schools and communities, so people know how the process works instead of relying on rumors or social media.

statements.statement: As someone who works hard for a living and just wants a fair shot, I think we need more transparency and standardization in how elections are run so people can actually see that every vote is counted correctly, no matter where you live. I’d like to see stronger protections against voter suppression, especially in Black communities, along with independent, nonpartisan oversight of voting machines, ballot counting, and audits. Making Election Day a national holiday, expanding early voting, and clear public reporting of results and audits would help people like me feel the system is accessible and honest.

statements.statement: We need to tighten up election security and make the process more transparent so people know the outcome is honest, not just told to trust it. That means strict voter ID, cleaning up voter rolls, and using paper ballots that can be audited and recounted. I’d also like to see bipartisan observers—Republicans and Democrats—clearly present at every step, from counting to certification, so no one can claim something was done in the shadows. When the rules are clear, enforced, and visible, people like me are much more likely to accept the results, win or lose.

statements.statement: As someone who’s pretty social and talks to a lot of different kinds of people, I think the best way to increase trust in U.S. elections is through radical transparency and easier access to clear, nonpartisan information about how votes are cast, counted, and audited. We should standardize strong paper trails and routine, independent audits nationwide, and make that process visible to the public through livestreams, open data, and community observers from all parties. I also think we need tougher consequences for politicians and media outlets that knowingly spread election disinformation, because that erodes trust more than any technical issue with the system itself.

statements.statement: As someone who manages complex projects for a living, I think the best way to increase trust in our elections is through transparency, accountability, and clear communication. We should invest in secure, auditable voting systems, require routine bipartisan audits, and make the results and processes easy for regular people to understand. I’d also like to see more nonpartisan, community-based voter education and observation efforts so that neighbors, churches, and local groups can see firsthand how the system works instead of relying on partisan spin.

statements.statement: As someone who’s voted in many elections and values our democracy, I think we need more transparency and less drama around how votes are cast and counted. Clear, nonpartisan information about voting rules, stronger protections against voter suppression, and routine public audits of election results would go a long way toward rebuilding trust. I’d also like to see better civics education and community forums where election officials answer questions directly, so people don’t have to rely on rumors or partisan spin.

statements.statement: As someone who works every day with families who feel overlooked or powerless, I think rebuilding trust in U.S. elections starts with radical transparency and real, accessible education about how the process works—from voter registration to ballot counting. We should invest in nonpartisan, multilingual outreach (including clear online tools and tech) that lets people see the safeguards in place, verify their own participation, and understand how disputes are handled. At the same time, we need strong, consistently enforced rules against misinformation and intimidation so people can vote without fear or confusion. When ordinary people, especially new citizens like me, can clearly see that every vote is protected and counted fairly, trust will follow.

statements.statement: As someone who manages crops for a living, I know that trust comes from transparency and being able to see how things are done, not just being told it’s all fine. To increase trust in US elections, we should invest in paper ballots, routine audits, and open, nonpartisan observation of vote counting so anyone can see the process is fair. We also need stronger protections against corporate and dark money influence, because people won’t believe in the results if they think big donors and special interests are calling the shots. Finally, robust public education about how elections actually work—down to the county level—would help folks feel as informed about their democracy as they are about their own communities.

statements.statement: As someone who spent her life teaching civics and history, I believe rebuilding trust in our elections starts with honest, accessible education about how the system actually works, from voter registration to ballot counting. We should ensure paper trails, transparent audits, and nonpartisan oversight so people can see that every valid vote is counted fairly. I’d also like to see more community forums at libraries, schools, and churches where election officials answer questions directly, so neighbors can replace rumors with real information. When people feel informed, included, and respected, faith in our democracy grows.

statements.statement: As someone who cares about this country and votes Republican, I think we need more transparency and accountability in our elections if we want people to trust the results. That means strict voter ID laws, cleaning up voter rolls, and making sure observers from both parties can clearly see what’s happening at every step. We should also tighten rules around mail-in ballots and have routine, independent audits of the vote so folks know the system is being checked. When people can see the process is fair and secure, they’ll be more willing to accept the outcome, win or lose.

statements.statement: At my age, I’ve seen a lot of elections come and go, and trust is built when the process is transparent and people feel included. We should expand nonpartisan election oversight, make voting easier and more accessible—especially for seniors and working people—and clearly explain how ballots are counted and audited. I’d also like to see stronger action against misinformation, and more civic education in our communities, so people understand the system instead of just hearing rumors.

statements.statement: I think we should make elections easier to understand and more transparent, like showing clearly how votes are counted and letting regular people observe the process, even livestreaming parts of it online. Schools should also teach more about how elections work so kids like me grow up knowing the system instead of just hearing rumors. If people could see for themselves that the rules are fair and the results are checked by both parties, they’d be more likely to trust the outcome, even when their side loses.
